        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br>Author: Nick Diego Yamane <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Nick Diego Yamane &lt;<!----></span>nickdiego@igalia.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/nickdiego@igalia.com"><!---->nickdiego@igalia.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<!----></span><br><br>tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<span class="line"><!---->tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<!----></span><br><br>As of<span class="line"><!---->As of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3465738<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3465738"><!---->crrev.com/c/3465738<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the browser window closing/destruction is no<span class="line"><!----> the browser window closing/destruction is no<!----></span><br>longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<span class="line"><!---->longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<!----></span><br>"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=sky<span class="line"><!---->R=sky<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1309461<a         Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<span class="line"><!---->Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<!----></span>security@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/security@chromium.org"><!---->security@chromium.org<!----></a>) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! Severity guidelines: <span class="line"><!---->) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you!         Re <span class="line"><!---->Re <!----></span>comment 30<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c30"><!---->comment 30<!----></a>: tsepez@ (sorry, had missed your comment, tab refresh was needed) Yes, this involves UAFs and was probably more easily reproducible after [1] (further details at <span class="line"><!---->: tsepez@ (sorry, had missed your comment, tab refresh was needed) Yes, this involves UAFs and was probably more easily reproducible after [1] (further details at <!----></span>bug 1309461<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1309461" title="[Regression] Single-tab chrome window does not get shut down when closed during a tab drag session "><!---->bug 1309461<!----></a>), so I'd say M101 and M102 are the versions affected. Setting the severity back to what you had previously set. Thanks<span class="line"><!---->), so I'd say M101 and M102 are the versions affected. Setting the severity back to what you had previously set. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=​sky<span class="line"><!---->R=​sky<!----></span><br><br>(cherry picked from         Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<span class="line"><!---->Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1308968#c56">Comment 56<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on

        Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <!----></span><br><br>While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <span class="line"><!---->While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <!----></span><br>If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<span class="line"><!---->If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<!----></span><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

      I think the repair of bug(<span class="line"><!---->I think the repair of bug(<!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1267791<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1267791"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1267791<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> is not perfect <span class="line"><!----> is not perfect <!----></span><br><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>1、enable wayland in linux<span class="line"><!---->1、enable wayland in linux<!----></span><br>2、out/asan/chrome --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland "<span class="line"><!---->2、out/asan/chrome --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland "<!----></span>http://localhost:8000/a.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:8000/a.html"><!---->http://localhost:8000/a.html<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span><br>3、open a new tab window<span class="line"><!---->3、open a new tab window<!----></span><br>4、drag the new tab and wait for the crash.<span class="line"><!---->4、drag the new tab and wait for the crash.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The attached gpu info lists "X11" as the Ozone Platform [1]. Can you please confirm whether does it really correspond to the Chromium instance running with Wayland backend (as described in the above description) ?<span class="line"><!---->The attached gpu info lists "X11" as the Ozone Platform [1].         The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br>Author: Nick Diego Yamane <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Nick Diego Yamane &lt;<!----></span>nickdiego@igalia.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/nickdiego@igalia.com"><!---->nickdiego@igalia.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<!----></span><br><br>tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<span class="line"><!---->tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<!----></span><br><br>As of<span class="line"><!---->As of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3465738<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3465738"><!---->crrev.com/c/3465738<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the browser window closing/destruction is no<span class="line"><!----> the browser window closing/destruction is no<!----></span><br>longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<span class="line"><!---->longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<!----></span><br>"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=sky<span class="line"><!---->R=sky<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1309461<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1309461" title="[Regression] Single-tab chrome window does not get shut down when closed during a tab drag session "><!---->Bug: 1309461<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>1297099<span class="line"><!---->1297099<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>1308968<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1308968" title="Use-after-free crash in WaylandWindow when tabdrag source window gets destroyed         Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<span class="line"><!---->Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<!----></span>security@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/security@chromium.org"><!---->security@chromium.org<!----></a>) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! Severity guidelines: <span class="line"><!---->) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=​sky<span class="line"><!---->R=​sky<!----></span><br><br>(cherry picked from         Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<span class="line"><!---->Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1308968#c56">Comment 56<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, May 13, 2022, 9:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <!----></span><br><br>While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <span class="line"><!---->While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <!----></span><br>If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<span class="line"><!---->If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<!----></span><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=sky<span class="line"><!---->R=sky<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1309461<a         Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<span class="line"><!---->Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<!----></span>security@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/security@chromium.org"><!---->security@chromium.org<!----></a>) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! Severity guidelines: <span class="line"><!---->) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=​sky<span class="line"><!---->R=​sky<!----></span><br><br>(cherry picked from commit <span class="line"><!---->(cherry picked from commit <!----></span>24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank"         Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<span class="line"><!---->Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <!----></span><br><br>While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <span class="line"><!---->While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <!----></span><br>If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<span class="line"><!---->If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<!----></span><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        adetaylor@ , nickdiego@<span class="line"><!---->adetaylor@ , nickdiego@<!----></span><br><br>I found the root cause of the crash to be this: <span class="line"><!---->I found the root cause of the crash to be this: <!----></span><br>It is closed while the TAB is dragging. It crashes when performing certain operations on the address bar, regardless of whether "--enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland" flags is turned on or not<span class="line"><!---->It is closed while the TAB is dragging.         This is likely caused by (or it's allowed to happen because of) a recent regression and affects not only Wayland backend, <span class="line"><!---->This is likely caused by (or it's allowed to happen because of) a recent regression and affects not only Wayland backend, <!----></span>issue 1309461<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1309461" title="[Regression] Single-tab chrome window does not get shut down when closed during a tab drag session "><!---->issue 1309461<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>for which I could already find out the culprit CL as well as a potential solution. After landing it, let's check if this is still reproducible somehow. Thanks for your detailed inputs.<span class="line"><!---->for which I could already find out the culprit CL as well as a potential solution.         The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br>Author: Nick Diego Yamane <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Nick Diego Yamane &lt;<!----></span>nickdiego@igalia.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/nickdiego@igalia.com"><!---->nickdiego@igalia.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<!----></span><br><br>tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<span class="line"><!---->tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<!----></span><br><br>As of<span class="line"><!---->As of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3465738<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3465738"><!---->crrev.com/c/3465738<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the browser window closing/destruction is no<span class="line"><!----> the browser window closing/destruction is no<!----></span><br>longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<span class="line"><!---->longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<!----></span><br>"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=sky<span class="line"><!---->R=sky<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1309461<a         Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<span class="line"><!---->Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<!----></span>security@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/security@chromium.org"><!---->security@chromium.org<!----></a>) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! Severity guidelines: <span class="line"><!---->) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you!         Re <span class="line"><!---->Re <!----></span>comment 30<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c30"><!---->comment 30<!----></a>: tsepez@ (sorry, had missed your comment, tab refresh was needed) Yes, this involves UAFs and was probably more easily reproducible after [1] (further details at <span class="line"><!---->: tsepez@ (sorry, had missed your comment, tab refresh was needed) Yes, this involves UAFs and was probably more easily reproducible after [1] (further details at <!----></span>bug 1309461<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1309461" title="[Regression] Single-tab chrome window does not get shut down when closed during a tab drag session "><!---->bug 1309461<!----></a>), so I'd say M101 and M102 are the versions affected. Setting the severity back to what you had previously set. Thanks<span class="line"><!---->), so I'd say M101 and M102 are the versions affected. Setting the severity back to what you had previously set. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=​sky<span class="line"><!---->R=​sky<!----></span><br><br>(cherry picked from         Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<span class="line"><!---->Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <!----></span><br><br>While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <span class="line"><!---->While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <!----></span><br>If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<span class="line"><!---->If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<!----></span><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e"><!---->24e8eac41d4067ff2e28c270c3e85ed3446ff36e<!----></a><br>Author: Nick Diego Yamane <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Nick Diego Yamane &lt;<!----></span>nickdiego@igalia.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/nickdiego@igalia.com"><!---->nickdiego@igalia.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Apr 12 17:11:37 2022<!----></span><br><br>tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<span class="line"><!---->tabdrag: properly close dragged window when tabstrip is getting empty<!----></span><br><br>As of<span class="line"><!---->As of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3465738<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3465738"><!---->crrev.com/c/3465738<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the browser window closing/destruction is no<span class="line"><!----> the browser window closing/destruction is no<!----></span><br>longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<span class="line"><!---->longer done using a posted task, instead it is called right away upon<!----></span><br>"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<span class="line"><!---->"tab strip empty" event. It turns out that, at that point, Widget::Close<!----></span><br>call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<span class="line"><!---->call will no-op due to TabStrip::IsTabstripCloseable() returns false,<!----></span><br>cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<span class="line"><!---->cause the drag session is still active, waiting for the nested move loop<!----></span><br>to finish.<span class="line"><!---->to finish.<!----></span><br><br>The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<span class="line"><!---->The side-effect is described in the linked crbug, and probably several<!----></span><br>other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<span class="line"><!---->other related subtle issues. This fixes it by adding including the<!----></span><br>above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<span class="line"><!---->above described state to the list of conditions that allow the tab strip<!----></span><br>to be closed.<span class="line"><!---->to be closed.<!----></span><br><br>R=sky<span class="line"><!---->R=sky<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1309461<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1309461" title="[Regression] Single-tab chrome window does not get shut down when closed during a tab drag session A<span class="line"><!---->window drag controller will keep alive until the drag session ends. A<!----></span><br>good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programatically<span class="line"><!---->good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programatically<!----></span><br>close the browser window.<span class="line"><!---->close the browser window.<!----></span><br><br>That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<span class="line"><!---->That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<!----></span><br>controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<span class="line"><!---->controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<!----></span><br>corruption / security issues. Unit tests are added to exercise these<span class="line"><!---->corruption / security issues. Unit tests are added to exercise these<!----></span><br>scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->scenarios.<!----></span><br><br>R=<span class="line"><!---->R=<!----></span>tonikitoo@igalia.com<a         Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<span class="line"><!---->Dear owner, thanks for fixing this bug. We’ve reopened it because security bugs need Security_Severity and FoundIn labels set, which will enable the bots to request merges to the correct branches ( as well as helping out our vulnerability reward and CVE processes). Please consult with any Chrome security contact (<!----></span>security@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/security@chromium.org"><!---->security@chromium.org<!----></a>) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! Severity guidelines: <span class="line"><!---->) to arrange to set these labels and then this bug can be marked closed again. Thank you! A<!----></span><br>good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programmatically<span class="line"><!---->good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programmatically<!----></span><br>close the browser window.<span class="line"><!---->close the browser window.<!----></span><br><br>That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<span class="line"><!---->That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<!----></span><br>controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<span class="line"><!---->controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<!----></span><br>corruption / security issues. A<!----></span><br>good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programmatically<span class="line"><!---->good example is a webapp using window.close() API to programmatically<!----></span><br>close the browser window.<span class="line"><!---->close the browser window.<!----></span><br><br>That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<span class="line"><!---->That said, this CL gets rid of some related assumptions in drag<!----></span><br>controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<span class="line"><!---->controller's code, hardening it against UaFs and other potential memory<!----></span><br>corruption / security issues.         Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<span class="line"><!---->Hello and thank you for this report. In reviewing the information and videos for VRP reward assessment, this issue appears to be a null pointer deref, so at this time, this issue is unfortunately ineligible for a VRP reward. If you can provide a symbolized stack trace from an asan build that demonstrates this uaf, we would be happy to review for a potential VRP reward. Thank you!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1308968#c56">Comment 56<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, May 13, 2022, 9:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, I'm sorry that you feel the reward decision on this issue is unfair. We do our best to analyze each report and provide fair and clear reward decisions. Unfortunately we don't have any evidence to support that this issue results in a UAF or any other memory corruption in the browser process. The only technical evidence we can see from the developer or your submission is that this results in a null pointer deref, and this was multiple engineers looking across multiple artifacts and your videos for us to make this determination. <!----></span><br><br>While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <span class="line"><!---->While we do appreciate your report and timely feedback, we can not provide a VRP reward based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref and without demonstration of  security implications resulting from this issue. As this issue requires some direct user interaction to trigger this bug, even if this were to be a security bug, exploitation potential is greatly reduced, and therefore we do need evidence this is a security issue with security implications. <!----></span><br>If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<span class="line"><!---->If you can provide technical evidence of a the UAF we would be happy to reassess for a potential reward amount, but based solely on evidence of a null pointer deref, we are unable to extend a reward. [1]<!----></span><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-aren_t-null-pointer-dereferences-considered-security-bugs<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        <div class="target-project-dialog">

      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

// Load and instantiate pRPC client before any other script.
window.prpcClient = new AutoRefreshPrpcClient(
 CS_env.token, CS_env.tokenExpiresSec);

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
